subject: Add configurable monitor timeouts for ovn dbs
commit_message:
Add configurable monitor timeouts for ovn dbs

Under pressure, the default monitor timeout value of 20 seconds is not
enough to prevent unnecessary failovers of the ovn-dbs pacemaker resource.
While spawning a few VMs in the same time this could lead to unnecessary
movements of master DB, then re-connections of ovn-controllers (slaves are
read-only), further peaks of load on DBs, and at the end it could lead to
snowball effect. Now this value can be configurable by
OVNDBSPacemakerTimeout which will configure
tripleo::profile::pacemaker::ovn_dbs_bundle (default is set to 60s)

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692120/

subject: Change horizon release model to cycle-with-intermediary
commit_message:
Change horizon release model to cycle-with-intermediary

It was discussed in the Shanghai PTG.
horizon has two aspects: the one is to provide GUI to users and
the other is a library for horizon plugins.
When horizon plugins would like to use recent changes or to avoid bugs,
they need to consume beta releases of horizon.
More frequent releases of horizon would make more sense.
This commit changes the release model to cycle-with-intemediary.

After this change, horizon major version will be bumped when both
user-visible features and horizon plugin interfaces are dropped.
This menas the horizon major version can potentially be bumped
multiple times in a single development cycle.

Change-Id: I494063ca132b362cb769468fc588d71ec6264ca6

subject: Configure mysqld with max_allowed_packet=16M
commit_message:
Configure mysqld with max_allowed_packet=16M

Based on [1] and seeing it's fairly common [2] configure mysql
to use max_allowed_packet=16M to avoid aborted connection issues
seen in grenade runs.

What we're seeing in bug 1844929 is that during a grenade run
upgrading to Train, mysqld is started three times (install, devstack
old side restart, devstack new side restart) and after the final
restart we start losing connections which manifest themselves during
nova scheduling with "Timed out waiting for response from cell"
errors trying to query the nova_cell1 database.

It's not clear what might have changed in Train. To figure that out
we likely need more verbose mysqld logging enabled in a patch that
hits the failure. But for now it seems useful to try and set
max_allowed_packet to a higher size as a workaround.

[1] https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/19135/mysql-error-reading-communication-packets/19139#19139
[2] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=max_allowed_packet&i=nope&files=&repos=

Change-Id: I2310d50dfbd704e522a45e023415c6a58fb43442
Related-Bug: #1844929

When the scheduler picks a destination host during live
migration and then the conductor task rejects the host for
some reason, like the destination hypervisor version is older
than the source, the conductor task tries to undo the allocations
created for the instance by the scheduler. This can result in

commit_message:
Set ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default

Cinder and etcd are enabled by default and by default
cinder uses etcd as a distributed lock manager with
tooz as an intermediary. We see a lot of ToozConnectionErrors [1]

cinder operations timing out causing test failures, like
when a volume is not deleted within a given time.

This changes ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default to try and
alleviate some of the pressure. An alternative is if we know
we're in a single-node job we could just not use a DLM for
Cinder.

This adds an online data migration routine for volume BDMs when

subject: Clear RT.compute_nodes entry if re-balance update fails
commit_message:
Clear RT.compute_nodes entry if re-balance update fails

During an ironic node rebalance from host1 to host2, there
can be a race where host2 detects the rebalance, adds the
ComputeNode object its ResourceTracker.compute_nodes dict
and then try to update/refresh associations for the resource
provider in placement. Between the time that host2 has
cached the ComputeNode object and refreshed associations in
placement, host1's update_available_resource periodic task
can run, detect it no longer manages the node, and consider
it orphaned and delete the compute node record from the nova
DB and the resource provider from placement. When the
resource provider is deleted via host1 in this race window,
the association refresh in host2 fails because the provider
is gone. As a result, host2 has stale entries in the RT
compute_nodes dict and possible the ProviderTree cache.

This resolves the issue by simply handling the failure
to refresh assocations and remove the RT.compute_nodes entry,
like the fix for bug 1839674, so that on the next run of
update_available_resource on host2 it will re-create the
compute node (note this depends on the fix for bug 1839560 to
"re-create" the soft deleted compute node record) and the
resource provider.

Change-Id: Iffb802cf9c84550e919d5b2865d05fe172907190
Closes-Bug: #1841481

subject: Add functional recreate test for bug 1841481
commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1841481

This is pretty hairy since it involves an ironic node
re-balance across two compute services and a race but
if you trust what is written in the test, which is
basically automating the log dive from the bug report,
this works and recreates the issue. The hairy bits are
in simulating the race because in the bug report things
are happening concurrently (obviously, it's a race across
two separate services on different compute hosts) but in
the test we're doing things in serial so we have to stub
out a few things to simulate what happens at each point
in time from the view of each service.

The main takeaways are that:

1. Once the node is re-balanced to host2, we cannot
   re-create the resource provider by simply running
   the update_available_resource periodic task, i.e.
   the issue is not self-healing.

2. The resource tracker on host2 has incorrectly cached
   in memory a ComputeNode and resource provider which are
   actually deleted so the cache is stale but we're not
   healing it automatically on failure.

subject: Switch to use cast method in dhcp_ready_on_ports method
commit_message:
Switch to use cast method in dhcp_ready_on_ports method

When DHCP agent reports to the neutron-server which ports are
ready, it was using call() method from rpc client.
That caused blocking dhcp agent's dhcp_ready_ports_loop thread which
blocks to send info about other ready ports if there are any.

Method call() should be used when RPC caller returns a value to the
caller but that's not the case here. On neutron server side this
RPC method is only calling provisioning_complete() method to
finish provisioning of ports. And is not returning anything.

So to make sending dhcp ready ports to neutron-server much faster
this patch switch to use cast() method from rpc client.
This method don't block to wait for return value from RPC caller.

Change-Id: Ie119693854aa283b863a1eac2bdae3330c2b6a9d

subject: Fix controller worker graceful shutdown
commit_message:
Fix controller worker graceful shutdown

Fix an issue that prevents graceful shutdown of controller workers.

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 300 seconds (set in devstack plugin) and can be
overriden using the graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf
The default value will be updated to a lower value when work on
persistant taskflow will be merged.

Only install python3 packages if necessary

In change I43de36ab570af40bc837d859568f5428c167f083, we started
installing the 'python3-' variants of the 'python-' packages installed
by the 'ceph-common' package in 'install_ceph_remote'. In that change,

the 'python3_enabled' function or 'USE_PYTHON3' variable since (a) these
packages can happily coexist, (b) projects should be switching to Python
3 now, and (c) using these would require sourcing additional, otherwise
unnecessary devstack libraries just to use this simple function".

versioned. This means *any* job that uses this plugin, including things

provide these 'python3-' variants, the command will always fail.

Start hiding the command behind a 'use_python3' function call. Hopefully
by time we drop Python 2 support here we won't have maintained branches

subject: Make upload workers faster on processing layers
commit_message:
Make upload workers faster on processing layers

Make upload workers processing image layers only once (as the best
effort). This also reworks and simplifies locks management for
individual tasks now managed for the PythonImageUploader class
namespace only.

When fetching source layer, cross-link it for the target
local image, whenever that source is already exists. When pushing a
layer to a target registry, do not repeat transfering the same data,
if already pushed earlier for another image.

The 1st time a layer gets uploaded/fetched for an image, that image and
its known path (local or remote) becomes a reference for future
cross-referencing by other images.

Store such information about already processed layers in global view
shared for all workers to speed-up data transfering jobs they execute.

Having that global view, uploading the 1st image in the tasks list as a
separate (and non-concurrent) job becomes redundant and now will be
executed concurently with other images.

Based on the dynamically picked multi-workers mode, provide the global
view as a graf with its MP/MT state synchronization as the following:

* use globally shared locking info also containing global layers view
  for MP-workers. With the shared global view state we can no longer
  use local locking objects individual for each task.
* if cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads-safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock also containing a safe from data
  races Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that optimizes:

* completion time
* re-fetching of the already processed layers
* local deduplication of layers
* the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
* if-layer-exists and other internal logic check executed against the
  in-memory cache firstly.

As layers locking and unlocking becomes a popular action, reduce the
noise of the debug messages it produces.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 46f81298948865a2c15c4a5035e95a0c77adb5d5)

Under pressure, the default monitor timeout value of 20 seconds is not

subject: Fix FC scan too broad
commit_message:
Fix FC scan too broad

After some changes to the FC connector we have introduced a regression
on the way we do the scans, and we end up scanning using wildcards even
though we shouldn't.

The targets in the "initiator_target_map" don't mean that they are all
connected, so we must take that into account.

With the current code, if we have the following connections:

HBA host7 ---- SWITCH ---- port W (channel 0, target 2)
          \--- SWITCH ---- port X (channel 0, target 3)

HBA host8 ---- SWITCH ---- port Y (channel 0, target 2)
          \--- SWITCH ---- port Z (channel 0, target 3)

We will end up with the following scans 8 scans for LUN L:

  - - L > host7
  - - L > host7
  0 2 L > host7
  0 3 L > host7

  0 2 L > host8
  0 3 L > host8
  - - L > host8
  - - L > host8

Which correspond to the responses from _get_hba_channel_scsi_target like
this:

               port Y          port Z          port W          port X
  host7 ... ['-','-',L]     ['-','-',L]     ['0','2',L]     ['0','3',L]
  host8 ... ['0','2',L]     ['0','3',L]     ['-','-',L]     ['-','-',L]

And we should only be doing 4 scans:

  0 2 L > host7
  0 3 L > host7
  0 2 L > host8
  0 3 L > host8

Most storage arrays get their target ports automatically detected by the
Linux FC initiator and sysfs gets populated with that information, but
there are some that don't.

We'll do a narrow scan using the channel, target, and LUN for the former
and a wider scan for the latter.

If all paths to a former type of array were down on the system boot the
array could look like it's of the latter type and make us bring us
unwanted volumes into the system by doing a broad scan.

To prevent this from happening Cinder drivers can use the
"enable_wildcard_scan" key in the connection information to let us know
they don't want us to do broad scans even if no target ports are found
(because they know the cause is there's no connection).

subject: Reset vm_state to original value if rebuild claim fails
commit_message:
Reset vm_state to original value if rebuild claim fails

If while evacuating an active or stopped server the rebuild
resource claim or group affinity policy check fails, the state
of the server has not actually changed but the vm_state is changed
to ERROR because of the _error_out_instance_on_exception context
manager.

This builds on Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb by
wrapping the BuildAbortException in InstanceFaultRollback for the
claim/group policy failures so the vm_state remains unchanged.
Note that the overall instance action record will still be marked
as a failure since the BuildAbortException is re-raised and the
wrap_instance_event decorator will fail the action (this is how the
user can know the operation failed).

an official project team in favor of a SIG. A "SIG" is a group

WIP: neutron: avoid redundant show_network calls in _get_physnet_tunneled_info

When building the network vif info model for an instance we already
build the list of networks for the ports associated with the server
and have the network match available for the port when calling
_get_physnet_tunneled_info from _nw_info_build_network (the detailed
call trace information is in the bug report).

This change leverages that network dict and passes it to
_get_physnet_tunneled_info to avoid redundant show_network calls
in that method.

TODOs are left in place for similar inefficiencies in the
create_resource_request method. test_rebuild_server_with_network_affinity

subject: Chunk BDM queries from ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances()
commit_message:
Chunk BDM queries from ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances()

Change I74864b398f2d17a24b9ed676945183401e9872a0 in Newton
made the ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances() method do
a single query to get all BDMs for the list of instances rather
than one query per instance to avoid storming conductor.

However, when running nova-compute with shared storage on the
[DEFAULT]/instances_path config option or with a clustered
hypervisor (vCenter), the number of instances to process could
be large which can timeout the query to get BDMs (the message query
to conductor times out after 60 seconds by default because of
the rpc_response_timeout config option).

This change chunks the BDM queries to groups of 50 instances
per query to avoid overloading conductor but also complete before
the rpc_response_timeout.

We could further optimize this code to only query swap BDMs, but
that requires changes to the RPC versioned BlockDeviceMappingList
interface and cannot be backported, so that change needs to be
made separately.

While in here, the image_cache_manager_interval configuration
option help is updated to (1) fix formatting on possible values,
(2) describe the "large number of instances" scenarios to watch
out for, (3) add related options and (4) clarify the "0" default
interval value so it is not confused with the 2400 default.

subject: Revert "Stop testing Python 2"
commit_message:
Revert "Stop testing Python 2"

This reverts commit 14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4.

I totally get that you have to switch at some point and it will not be
pain free ... however ...

As of right now the patch to convert devstack to Python 3 by default
is still in WIP [1].  This means basically devstack is by default
broken by this (the setup.cfg change means that pip will bail when
installing with Python 2).

This flows on to other jobs; for example consumers of install-devstack
role [2] take defaults and are thus broken too.  I'm sure there will
be other examples.

I feel like we should make sure the devstack defaults are Python 3
first, give people a little time to deal with that, and then switch
this over.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/
[2] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/install-devstack

Change-Id: I816c2647c5bbdddfca2a623ee14e80793a23c045
